page.title: 10FREEMINING
page.content: Mining in the forest almost certainly goes back to the Iron Age and in Norman times iron was so important to the nation's economy and security that the iron miner and blacksmith became privileged; perhaps here freemining has its origins. The inhabitants of Dean won acclaim in the reign of Edward I for their military activities at the Seige of Berwick and were rewarded with rights to mine within the Hundred of St. Briavels (much of the Forest of Dean). To qualify as a freeminer a man must be born in this area and have worked in a mine for a year and a day. He can then apply to the Deputy Gaveller for a 'gale' - the right to mine a certain area. Few active such mines exist today; one in this area at Danby Lodge is worked by two men and produces coal for themselves and power stations.
